commit_message:
Add functional regression test for bug 1669054

Change Ic3968721d257a167f3f946e5387cd227a7eeec6c in Newton
started setting the RequestSpec.ignore_hosts field to the
source instance.host during resize/cold migrate if
allow_resize_to_same_host=False in config, which it is by
default.

Change I8abdf58a6537dd5e15a012ea37a7b48abd726579 also in
Newton persists changes to the RequestSpec in conductor
in order to save the RequestSpec.flavor for the new flavor.
This inadvertently persists the ignore_hosts field as well.

Later if you try to evacuate or unshelve the server it will ignore
the original source host because of the persisted ignore_hosts value.
This is obviously a problem in a small deployment with only a few
compute nodes (like an edge deployment). As a result, an evacuation
can fail if the only available host is the one being ignored.

This adds a functional regression recreate test for the bug.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/api/client.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
I71e9d8dae55653ad3ee70f708a6d92c98ed20c1c in Ocata which
added the 201 value to the check_response_status default.

NOTE(mriedem): This backport differs slightly in that
(a) REQUIRES_LOCKING is removed and NeutronFixture is
used explicitly since change I9b35ed7497db8bd1eb74f4bb89631aabbcfeec0d
is not in Ocata and (b) kwargs are passed through post_server_action
because change If7b02bcd8d77e94c7fb42b721792c1391bc0e3b7 is not in
Ocata.

Change-Id: I6ce2d6b1baf47796f867aede1acf292ec9739d6d
Related-Bug: #1669054
(cherry picked from commit 556cf103b22ab6bebecc9d824d6f918cda38fe3e)
(cherry picked from commit 20c1414945db633ed00c1f19f1f0d163028454d9)
(cherry picked from commit 77164128bf5eef53b49547658be2ef902c020207)
(cherry picked from commit 9fd4082d7c076146ec314b86e0e4772d0a021712)
(cherry picked from commit fcd718dcdd3cb7ba46f16ff97ecee068d55c8801)

commit_message:
Remove old Heat hosts entries in tripleo-hosts-entries

For upgrades, this role now takes care of removing the old Heat entries
if they are present in /etc/hosts. The test prepare process has been
updated to create a temp file that would replicate what we'd expect
in a live system.

Change-Id: Ifc4d9553b74e6e6a9794902b418f54c0cfc7a39d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-31 17:05:54.000000000', 'message': "WIP service: Do not perform version checks for deleted services

WIP as this seems obvious, sligthtly too obvious.

Downstream we've seen ServiceTooOld raised after the following steps:

- Deploy Newton and populate with test instances.
- Delete these instances and redeploy the compute services.
- Upgrade from Newton to Queens and then to Rocky.
- Attempt to list --all instances in the env without archiving deleted
  rows first.

Avoiding version checks for deleted services seems to make sense here
but I'm sure I'm missing something...

Change-Id: I9784079a67dd0785b104a92d0245c233a759398f
"}]
commit_message:
WIP service: Do not perform version checks for deleted services

WIP as this seems obvious, sligthtly too obvious.

Downstream we've seen ServiceTooOld raised after the following steps:

- Deploy Newton and populate with test instances.
- Delete these instances and redeploy the compute services.
- Upgrade from Newton to Queens and then to Rocky.
- Attempt to list --all instances in the env without archiving deleted
  rows first.

Avoiding version checks for deleted services seems to make sense here
but I'm sure I'm missing something...

Change-Id: I9784079a67dd0785b104a92d0245c233a759398f

commit_message:
Use hiera interpolation for memcached_network

After [1] iptables rules are not set for memcached service
thus services relying on memcached were not functioning well.
With [2] it's requrired to use hiera interpolation for service
configs, this patch fixes it for memcached_network.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/551292
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/526692

Related-Bug: #1757556
Closes-Bug: #1763009
Change-Id: If9b274192ea4738f455a6106ff1a62eb4e7a5c91
(cherry picked from commit d3d27d7ea84fe01320dee3e4fa2e2fad11640eb7)

commit_message:
Restart certmnonger after registering system with IPA

If certmonger is not restarted when the server is registered with
IPA, then it may define the IPA CA as unreachable.  This results
in CA certs not being stored when cert requests are made with a -F
option.  Eventually, certmonger refreshes itself, but this can
take up to 8 hours.

We see this sometimes when doing brownfield deploys.  The ca cert
fails to be created for some requests, resulting in containers
being unable to load.

We fix this by simply restarting certmonger after enrollment, and
avoiding the whole confused state.

Closes-Bug: 1850647
Change-Id: Id968a2d5170af1485417e41318e0187d79cd4aae
(cherry picked from commit bf0bc85ef42bd8d8b3540b1388d64c60e43a8907)

Restart certmnonger after registering system with IPA

If certmonger is not restarted when the server is registered with
IPA, then it may define the IPA CA as unreachable.  This results
in CA certs not being stored when cert requests are made with a -F
option.  Eventually, certmonger refreshes itself, but this can
take up to 8 hours.

We see this sometimes when doing brownfield deploys.  The ca cert
fails to be created for some requests, resulting in containers
being unable to load.

avoiding the whole confused state.

commit_message:
Restart certmnonger after registering system with IPA

If certmonger is not restarted when the server is registered with
IPA, then it may define the IPA CA as unreachable.  This results
in CA certs not being stored when cert requests are made with a -F
option.  Eventually, certmonger refreshes itself, but this can
take up to 8 hours.

We see this sometimes when doing brownfield deploys.  The ca cert
fails to be created for some requests, resulting in containers
being unable to load.

We fix this by simply restarting certmonger after enrollment, and
avoiding the whole confused state.

Closes-Bug: 1850647
Change-Id: Id968a2d5170af1485417e41318e0187d79cd4aae
(cherry picked from commit bf0bc85ef42bd8d8b3540b1388d64c60e43a8907)

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I5b8be636db1e4d0f726e19993d1c83fda6c23ccf
Related-Bug: 1801465

Abandoning as it looks like this is no longer of interest.'}]

commit_message:
Add checksum-fill rule for DHCP packets

This calls into Neutron's DeviceManager.fill_dhcp_udp_checksums
function to ensure a rule is added for filling correct UDP checksums
on DHCP packets being sent to VMs. This is particularly a problem
when vhost_net kernel module is used according to the redhat bug
linked below.

Some associated bug reports at:
- https://github.com/projectcalico/felix/issues/40
- https://github.com/projectcalico/felix/issues/709
- https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=910619#c6

Change-Id: I9f14db8e8f3b44582e9c59056902c92310f534a1
Closes-Bug: #1629309
Co-Authored-By: Sam Yaple <sam@yaple.net>

messages: [{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-30 04:41:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-30 05:22:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-30 06:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-10-31 02:37:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-10-31 16:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-30 04:41:20.000000000', 'message': 'Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

watcher-dashboard is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691178/

commit_message:
Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

watcher-dashboard is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691178/

Change-Id: Ibc21e289b146e7c4ce4a5c20198c1d26fd97b604

commit_message:
Initial commit to os_murano role

This is the initial commit to the development of
os_murano role. It contains scaffolding and basic
functionality for installing murano.

Debian is set to non-voting as python3.5 fails when
binary passed to the json.loads().

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/679496

Change-Id: Ib006dc0578f436076cfe196c8574106e3dc7cbc6

subject: Allocate DHCP ports for agent

@Alex - thanks for working on this!

Apart from the change that this patchset is ostensibly for - i.e. enabling Calico DHCP operation without a gateway IP being defined - this work is raising a few other issues:

- Some refactoring of the existing code, e.g. (1) one 'datamodel_v1' import, and then using 'datamodel_v1.' prefix; (2) creating _create_endpoint and _update_endpoint routines.  I would prefer to see those changes in separate patches - then it would be easy for me to approve those patches, and _this_ change would be easier to understand because it would be smaller.

- Using neutron-lib for master, but somehow checking that networking-calico still works with Kilo/Liberty/Mitaka/Newton releases as well - which I believe is currently the case.  Do you know if there is a way that we can do this using OpenStack CI?

- The problem that our UT has started failing; specifically the test_build_cmdline test, as in your UT output at http://logs.openstack.org/45/392645/4/check/gate-networking-calico-python27-ubuntu-xenial/64fd934/testr_results.html.gz.  But you can also see this at e.g. http://logs.openstack.org/59/394459/1/check/gate-networking-calico-python27-ubuntu-xenial/1b9731f/testr_results.html.gz - so that particular test failure is not caused by your change here.

I'd certainly like the refactoring to be separated out, and ideally I would like to see those other two issues addressed first as well, so that I can then be much more confident when reviewing the actual DHCP port change that you are proposing here.  Would you have any interest in working on those things, or have suggestions for me what to do about them?"}, {'account_id': 11898, 'date': '2016-11-10 09:04:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Neil, 

Thank you for the review. I'll split this patch into smaller pieces and submit for review.

> Do you know if there is a way that we can do this using OpenStack CI?

AFAIK it's possible to run gate tests for specific OpenStack versions, but I need to clarify how to configure CI for this. 
I'll fix compatibility issues in my patch to support previous versions in the same master branch."}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2016-11-10 10:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Neil, I figured out why at least one of three tests fails. I checked test_hotplug_nic test and it appears that it hasn't fail before just because it was checking nothing.

This test works like this:

1. Tempest creates private network (let's say "net1") with gateway.
2. It spawns a VM with single interface in the network "net1".
3. Then it creates new network ("net2") and attaches interface to VM.
4. To check connectivity it tries to ping all existing addresses in "net2".

It passed just because in net2 without default GW simply was no IP addresses except VM's address itself. So basically tempest doesn't check this case and it checks nothing, due to empty loop (https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/scenario/test_network_basic_ops.py#L340)

So when we added new DHCP port, tempest started trying to ping it and since DHCP interface is not responding for ICMP requests, test fails.

In addition I checked why DHCP interface is not responding. It seems that packages just dropped by iptables, so probably we can address this issue.

Two other tests still have to be checked.'}, {'account_id': 11898, 'date': '2016-12-08 15:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-12-08 17:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Verified+1

@Alex - thanks once again for working on this change.  I am thinking it through; FYI following is my analysis so far - please do let me know if anything looks wrong.

Etcd datamodel
- /calico/dhcp/v1/port/<id>
Mech driver
- Port is for DHCP if device_id begins with 'dhcp-'.
- _update_dhcp_port: Maintain a DHCP port per network with a fixed IP
  for each DHCP-enabled subnet.
- Call self._update_dhcp_port when subnet is created or updated or
  deleted.
- Call self.transport.update_dhcp_port when DHCP-enabled subnet
  created or updated or deleted.
- Call self.transport.delete_dhcp_port when DHCP port is deleted.
- Write/delete DHCP port datamodel.  (1 DHCP port per network.)  Etcd
  data is a passthrough of the Neutron port data.
DHCP agent
- Expect FakePlugin never to be used.
- Watch a higher-level key (DHCP_DIR instead of SUBNET_DIR).
- Handler for /calico/dhcp/v1/port/<id>: on_dhcp_port_set:
  resync_after_current_poll.
- On resync: read all DHCP ports and store in self.dhcp_ports dict.
- Look for a DHCP port 'dhcp-<network ID>'.
- Don't expect ever to have to create the DHCP port ourselves.
- _ensure_net_and_subnets: get DHCP port from self.dhcp_ports and add
  it into NetModel.
- Set ipv6 fields to None for a v4 subnet.
RoutedInterfaceDriver
- Remove use_gateway_ips property.
- Changes to parameter defaults for init_l3.
Test code

So in summary I think there are a few logical changes happening here.

1. The DHCP port ID (get_device_id) is changed to be per-network,
   instead of per-(network, host).  If we use Neutron IP allocations,
   this is sufficient to ensure that we only burn 1 Neutron IP
   allocation per DHCP-enabled subnet, instead of 1 per subnet per
   host.

2. The logic for ensuring that a DHCP port has an IP for each subnet
   is now duplicated in the Calico mechanism driver (where I say
   'duplicated' because this logic already exists in Neutron's
   DeviceManager._setup_existing_dhcp_port).

3. The Calico mechanism driver also creates/updates the DHCP port in
   the Neutron DB, and uses etcd to pass information about this port
   to the updated Calico DHCP agent.  In comparison:

   - The existing Calico DHCP agent suppresses creating a DHCP port in
     the Neutron DB, using a FakePlugin.

   - The Neutron DHCP agent drives creating and updating the DHCP
     port, over Neutron RPC.

4. The Calico DHCP agent adds the DHCP port into the NetModel, as soon
   as it sees it in etcd, so that
   DeviceManager._setup_existing_dhcp_port will find it and not think
   that it needs to create a new port."}, {'account_id': 13734, 'date': '2017-01-05 15:36:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

@Alex - so, following the previous analysis, I am wondering if we might be able to make this change smaller and simpler, broadly speaking by:

- keeping parts (1) and (4) from your currently proposed change.

- instead of parts (2) and (3), using more of the existing Neutron agent+server code to maintain the DHCP port.

I should also mention something that is probably far from obvious to you, which is that we still support networking-calico master with OpenStack Kilo, and for that combination we still use the Neutron DHCP agent, not the Calico DHCP agent.  So really we need the changes here to work with the Neutron DHCP agent (perhaps with some small tweaks) as well as with the Calico DHCP agent.

(For Kilo we maintain a small patch to the vanilla Neutron code, which you can see at https://github.com/projectcalico/calico-neutron/commits/calico_2015.1.4.)

In general, I think it would be better to avoid - if we can - further architecture divergence between the Neutron DHCP agent and the Calico DHCP agent.  This will allow us to continue switching between them, and possibly even drop the Calico DHCP agent again if Neutron fixes the performance issues that motivated us to make our own agent.

Hence, if we are going to have DHCP ports with Neutron-allocated IPs, I wonder if we can keep the architecture of the DHCP port creation/update being driven from the DHCP agent?

In particular, I wonder if we could use normal Neutron RPC to create and update the DHCP port, while still _not_ using Neutron RPC for signaling all the other ports?

What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 14167, 'date': '2017-02-28 07:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-02-28 07:56:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Verified-1

commit_message:
Allocate DHCP ports for agent

Calico dhcp agent created dhcp interface with gateway IP address
assigned.

With this patch neutron server pre-allocates DHCP port,
which allows to reserve single IP address shared between DHCP
agents and distinct from gateway address.

Neutron server allocates one DHCP port per network and deletes
it if network doesn't have any subnet with DHCP enabled.

Closes-Bug: #1541490
Closes-Bug: #1625209
Change-Id: Ib60394366d25ab5ffb51fe5827b0a273d3d71aee

commit_message:
Run the allowed address pair test

This case tests that the Calico plugin supports the allowed address
pair extension, but it doesn't test actual inbound connection to the
allowed address pair IP address.

I think it's just worth having for the extension checking, even
without checking actual connectivity.

Change-Id: I71276c7300b0b3fb9776f29738c440db33aa25e7

commit_message:
Remove unwanted executable bits on calico-dhcp-agent.service

systemd reports when installing networking-calico:

Change-Id: If7788e5ff577979406b401e25b9db064e286bbd4

commit_message:
Correct ovn-dbs upgrade image id variable

In I8b5b25d03b86b2c44b2d47e5a0624e7dd13873da the variable
ovn_dbs_image_id was renamed to old_ovn_dbs_image_id but
one instance of it was left behind. This patch corrects
that.

Related-Bug: #1838971
Closes: rhbz#1758578
Change-Id: I5735210aad47411fdeb62d4dab45b1150ec3ea04
(cherry picked from commit 41a17bfc1a4326f19a94e1ed7092790fae51ae8d)

commit_message:
Add consts for OVN install path

As suggested in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/686432/ this
patch adds the following constants to ovsdbapp, so it can
be referred by other repos, such as networking-ovn:

- OVS_INSTALL_SHARE_PATH
- OVN_INSTALL_SHARE_PATH

Change-Id: I287ee1ca7cc68d9e5ec0acc8ab77371d89933e2e

commit_message:
Create an endpoint entry for novajoin

On a nova-less undercloud, the novajoin endpoint needs to be
discoverable by a mistral workflow without any configuration file
entry.

This change does this by creating an endpoint entry for novajoin.
There is already a keystone service entry created for novajoin, so
this change creates the endpoint which probably should have existed
anyway.  novajoin is accessed directly instead of through haproxy, so
the endpoint URL is created manually instead of through EndpointMap.

Change-Id: I0d307bec3771c7b03cbad2bb8ac0c1f20eb9baf3
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

[{'created': '2019-10-31 11:01:10.000000000', 'message': "Ignore ssh-keyscan errors on hosts

The linked bug is due to a computed shorthost name that is taken as the
first 'word' in a dotted fqdn provided by rDNS when resolving the IP
address of a nova-compute host.  However, depending on the DNS server,
this shorthost may not actually exist in the DNS server.  This patchset
ignores ssh-keyscans where effectively the host can't be reached and so
the shorthost is not added.

Change-Id: I9ca82e00a79a3eecf37231620f648683edc0bc95
Closes-Bug: #1849501
"}, {'created': '2019-10-31 14:13:24.000000000', 'message': "Ignore ssh-keyscan errors on hosts

The linked bug is due to a computed shorthost name that is taken as the
first 'word' in a dotted fqdn provided by rDNS when resolving the IP
address of a nova-compute host.  However, depending on the DNS server,

ignores ssh-keyscans where effectively the host can't be reached and so
the shorthost is not added.

Change-Id: I9ca82e00a79a3eecf37231620f648683edc0bc95

"}]
commit_message:
Ignore ssh-keyscan errors on hosts

The linked bug is due to a computed shorthost name that is taken as the
first 'word' in a dotted fqdn provided by rDNS when resolving the IP
address of a nova-compute host.  However, depending on the DNS server,
this shorthost may not actually exist in the DNS server.  This patchset
ignores ssh-keyscans where effectively the host can't be reached and so
the shorthost is not added.

Change-Id: I9ca82e00a79a3eecf37231620f648683edc0bc95
Closes-Bug: #1849501

commit_message:
Explicitly use Python 2 in the stable jobs

With ironic-base switched to Python 3 all jobs here are running with it.
This change reverts the stable jobs to their previous Python version.

Change-Id: I90499406d4848c1a5ff9e275d9f8dee6e3c98684

subject: Add configurable monitor timeouts for ovn dbs
messages: [{'account_id': 11082, 'date': '2019-10-30 12:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-10-31 09:51:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-30 12:20:28.000000000', 'message': 'Add configurable monitor timeouts for ovn dbs

Under pressure, the default monitor timeout value of 20 seconds is not
enough to prevent unnecessary failovers of the ovn-dbs pacemaker resource.
While spawning a few VMs in the same time this could lead to unnecessary
movements of master DB, then re-connections of ovn-controllers (slaves are
read-only), further peaks of load on DBs, and at the end it could lead to
snowball effect. Now this value can be configurable by dbs_timeout in
tripleo::profile::pacemaker::ovn_dbs_bundle and by default is set to 60s.

Change-Id: Ib95c6b7614631eed264d42e6cf61672b705e7893
Signed-off-by: Kamil Sambor <ksambor@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15e21010a8a8594678afe385821ee804ec9e16c7)
(cherry picked from commit 223e786c5716015c7ac1bdda94feabcd9c79716a)
(cherry picked from commit 98042540864790372980ede921f4d3960140c20e)
'}]
commit_message:
Add configurable monitor timeouts for ovn dbs

Under pressure, the default monitor timeout value of 20 seconds is not
enough to prevent unnecessary failovers of the ovn-dbs pacemaker resource.
While spawning a few VMs in the same time this could lead to unnecessary
movements of master DB, then re-connections of ovn-controllers (slaves are
read-only), further peaks of load on DBs, and at the end it could lead to
snowball effect. Now this value can be configurable by dbs_timeout in
tripleo::profile::pacemaker::ovn_dbs_bundle and by default is set to 60s.

Change-Id: Ib95c6b7614631eed264d42e6cf61672b705e7893
Signed-off-by: Kamil Sambor <ksambor@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 15e21010a8a8594678afe385821ee804ec9e16c7)
(cherry picked from commit 223e786c5716015c7ac1bdda94feabcd9c79716a)
(cherry picked from commit 98042540864790372980ede921f4d3960140c20e)
